abstracts.cdata!:
The Nakivubo Channel Rehabilitation
            Project for Uganda had the following ratings: the outcome
            was satisfactory, the sustainability was likely, the
            institutional development impact was Modest, and the Bank
            and borrower performance were both satisfactory. The lessons
            learned indicate that institutional change processes are
            difficult and will encounter resistance. Political will is
            critical to effect institutional change and must be
            carefully managed through election turnovers. Institutional
            change processes cannot be included as a small subcomponent
            in a 2-3 year project but must be core project objectives or
            provided in a separate project. Supporting mechanisms to
            increase accountability and transparency of local
            governments (e.g. private sector associations, media, NGOs,
            council committees, communities) are key to ensuring an
            early warning system and to improving commitment to reform
            local finances and service delivery, especially through
            election changes. Maintenance for large investments is tied
            up with overall financial management (expenditure and
            revenues) of municipality and cannot be treated as wholly
            separate. With proper planning, supervision and monitoring,
            the private sector can provide better quality services more
            competitively in certain service areas. Basic management
            techniques and systems are critical inputs to improving
            performance and accountability and need to be
            institutionalized early on in project life. Projects of this
            nature and scale can be properly managed by local
            consultants with limited support from international consultants.

5084454.trustfund:
TF037946-UGANDA - NAKIVUBO CHANNEL
            REHABILITATION PROJECT,TF040216-UGANDA - SUPERVISION OF URBAN
            DEVELOPMENT AND MANAGEMENT PROJECTS
5084454.majtheme: Environment and natural resource management,Urban development,Social protection and risk management

abstracts.cdata!:
The Nakivubo Channel Rehabilitation
            project will alleviate the frequent flood incidence on the
            road network, which affects traffic flows, with an adverse
            impact on the economic activity and living conditions in
            Kampala. Institutionally, the Project will enhance the
            Kampala City Council (KCC) management capacity, helping
            establish the infrastructure investment policies, and
            ultimately, support KCC's reform program. The project
            components include civil works regarding the rehabilitation
            of the main channel, construction of auxiliary drains, and,
            the rehabilitation of priority drainage. Consulting services
            for construction supervision will be financed by the
            project, as will the required program and policy studies,
            namely the Kampala Drainage Master Plan Study and the
            Kampala Urban Transportation Improvement Program Study.
            Institutional strengthening will support both, the KCC
            reform program under the strategic framework for reform, and
            the revenue enhancement program. To facilitate outsourcing
            of basic delivery functions, seed funds will be available,
            and training and implementation support will be further provided.

442335.trustfund:
TF040216-UGANDA - SUPERVISION OF URBAN
            DEVELOPMENT AND MANAGEMENT PROJECTS,TF037946-UGANDA - NAKIVUBO CHANNEL
            REHABILITATION PROJECT

repnme.cdata!:
Uganda - Nakivubo Channel Rehabilitation
            Project - environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This is an environmental assessment for
            the Nakivubo Channel Rehabilitation Project for Uganda,
            which includes deepening and widening the main stormwater
            drainage channel in Kampala in order to accommodate the
            1-in-10-year return period storm flow. These are the adverse
            environmental impacts and mitigation measures. Construction
            will likely cause damage to some of the flora and fauna in
            the area, soil erosion, and adverse aesthetic impacts. Also,
            the transport of substantial volumes of materials to and
            from the construction site will cause noise, dust, traffic
            disruption, and adverse aesthetic impacts. Limiting the work
            areas to be cleared ahead of construction, and revegetating
            bank slopes will arrest vegetal removal and the resulting
            loss of fauna habitat as well as soil erosion. Also,
            excavated areas below flood water levels will be treated and
            stone gabions and mattresses used. A traffic management plan
            including details of lane closures and bridges to be closed,
            proposed diversions, durations of interruptions, time
            restrictions on vehicular movements, and construction of
            footbridges will mitigate traffic disruption. To minimize
            flooding during channel construction, the contract documents
            will include restrictions on construction during the rainy
            season and the use of diversionary works.
